Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Work in the Time of COVID-19

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: Gig work, which is often conducted on platforms such as Uber, TaskRabbit, Instacart, Care.com, and Rover, is the epitome of precarious work: the work is so temporary that a 'gig' may last only a few minutes, and workers -- who are usually classified as independent contractors -- are entirely outside the social safety net of workersâ€™ compensation, social security contributions, paid leave, or health insurance. Traditionally, low-income workers have fared worse physically, psychologically, and economically in U.S. natural disasters. Also, while white collar and professional workers conduct their work remotely via Zoom, working from the relative safety of their home offices, gig and temporary workers are increasingly being called on to ensure ready access to food, medicine, and toilet paper for their middle and upper middle class work-from-home peers. And the ranks of precarious workers on the frontlines of the pandemic are only expected to grow. This project will examine the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on exacerbating the existing vulnerability of precarious and gig workers. This project will additionally examine how precarious workers in essential jobs are weighing, and addressing, the health risks of working versus the economic repercussions of unemployment, and how the pandemic, and resulting recession, may affect worker views of the desirability of freelance or gig-based work. Findings from the project will help to inform governmental policies at several levels affecting gig workers, as well as labor force participants who may be considering adoption or rejection of gig work in the 21st century. <br/><br/>The COVID-19 pandemic has challenged the working conditions of gig workers who, by definition, cannot practice social distancing when completing their tasks. This project, a mixed-methods panel study, will utilize in-depth interviews and surveys with 200 precarious and gig workers in New York City (NYC), the early epicenter of the COVID-19 outbreak. Participants will include gig workers who find work via online platforms, freelance workers in creative fields, and fast food and retail workers. The first phase will be conducted between April and June 2020, a period that coincides with the expected peak of the outbreak in NYC, and will examine how workers are coping with these risks, and how the pandemic is shaping their lives and understandings of their work. Follow-up interviews and surveys will be conducted during Fall 2020, concurrent with the expected second outbreak, and will provide an opportunity to study the impact of the Pandemic Unemployment Act and economic stimulus checks on gig workers. Findings from the project will inform sociological theories regarding precarious work, job satisfaction, and job mobility. Findings will also inform theories regarding differential access to the U.S. employment social safety net that appear among gig workers, as well as between them and workers in more conventional jobs.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project, a mixed-methods panel study, utilized in-depth phone interviews and online surveys with 200 precarious and gig workers in New York City (NYC), the early epicenter of the COVID-19 outbreak. Participants included workers who found work via online gig platforms; freelance workers in creative fields; and fast food, retail, and non-medical essential workers.

The first phase of data collection occurred primarily between April and June 2020 (a handful of interviews were conducted in August 2020), a period that coincided with the peak of the outbreak in NYC. The Phase I interviews and surveys focused on how workers were coping with the risk of the pandemic, and how the pandemic was shaping their lives and understandings of their work.

In the Phase I interviews, we found that for some respondents, frustration with the bureaucracy surrounding unemployment, partnered with uncertainty about their eligibility for unemployment, dissuaded them from applying for benefits and led them into gig employment or other precarious work. We found that workers in our sample experienced three main barriers in regards to accessing unemployment assistance and their experiences of unemployment that can be broadly categorized as knowledge, sociological, and temporal/financial hurdles.  Drawing on worker interview responses, we have named these responses: (1) Didn't Know, (2) Didn't Want, and (3) Can't Wait. As a result, rather than safely socially distancing at home, some workers turned to gig work to make ends meet, further highlighting the inequities of the pandemic, and turning so-called "side hustles" into their primary social safety net. These findings are discussed in more detail in "The Side Hustle Safety Net: Precarious Workers and Gig Work during COVID-19," published in the journal Sociological Perspectives.

In the Phase I data collection, we also found that while respondents increased their media consumption at the onset of the pandemic, that they soon complained of media sensationalism and repurposed a readily available cultural tool: claims of "fake news." As a result, these unsettled times have resulted in a "diffusion of distrust," in which an elite conservative discourse of skepticism toward the media has also become a popular form of compensatory control among self-identified liberals. Perceiving "fake news" and media sensationalism as "not good" for their mental health, respondents also reported experiencing media burnout and withdrawing from media consumption. These findings are discussed in more detail in "'The Looming, Crazy Stalker Coronavirus': Fear Mongering, Fake News, and the Diffusion of Distrust," which was published in Socius.

The Phase II follow-up interviews and surveys were conducted in late Fall 2020 and continued through Spring 2021, to coincide with the pandemic's second surge. Approximately 170 respondents from Phase I participated in the Phase II data collection, an attrition rate of roughly 15 percent. This phase of the research provided the opportunity to study the impact of the Pandemic Unemployment Act and economic stimulus checks on gig workers.

We found that as the enhanced unemployment assistance was reduced, some workers turned to unique financial "survival strategies" in order to make ends meet, including day trading and securing additional gig-based work, both on and off-platform. Additionally, as part of the Phase II interviews and surveys, we found that respondents also reported a changing conception of free time. Whereas most workers initially perceived free time in terms of opportunity costs, they later reconceived this time as enabling an investment in personal growth. This shift in temporal experience is expressed through the adoption of a "work passion" logic that motivated respondents to seek self-affirming careers and other "pandemic epiphanies," which may have contributed to an increase in new business starts during the pandemic.

These findings suggest that work passion ideology has been adopted by workers outside the creative industries, and that the pursuit of passion among low-wage precarious workers can inspire these workers to actively search for more fulfilling and potentially lucrative jobs.  Among precarious service and gig workers, however, the embrace of the passion principle may also be contributing to a rejection of stressful and poorly compensated service jobs and the growth of the so-called Great Resignation.

In ongoing research we are analyzing vaccine reluctance among precarious and gig-based workers and the resulting impact of vaccine mandates and incentives. We are also examining the impact of long-term unemployment on workers life chances and how turning to gig-based work during the crisis may affect workers' careers, which will allow us to generalize the findings reported above.
